item.title: WordPress in a Docker Container
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Docker is a container management system. It is used to manage an application that has multiple components. Docker-compose is a toolkit provided by Docker. It defines and runs a multi-container Docker application.

The YAML file

Create a docker-compose.yml file into your project directory:

version: '3'

services:

  db:
    image: mysql:5.7
    volumes:
      - db_data:/var/lib/mysql
    restart: always
    environment:
      MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD: db_pass
      MYSQL_DATABASE: wp_db
      MYSQL_USER: wp_user
      MYSQL_PASSWORD: wp_pass

  wordpress:
    depends_on:
      - db
    image: wordpress:5.8.2-php7.4-apache
    ports:
      - "8000:80"
    restart: always
    environment:
      WORDPRESS_DB_HOST: db:3306
      WORDPRESS_DB_NAME: wp_db
      WORDPRESS_DB_USER: wp_user
      WORDPRESS_DB_PASSWORD: wp_pass
    working_dir: /var/www/html
    volumes:
      - ./wp-content:/var/www/html/wp-content
      - ./uploads.ini:/usr/local/etc/php/conf.d/uploads.ini

volumes:
  db_data:

If you want to change the port that the WordPress install will use, just change the 8000 value in ports to whatever value you would like. If you want it to run on port 9210 you would make the change like so:

ports:
  - "9210:80"

Then instead of localhost:8000, the URL would be localhost:9210.

The first volumes parameter (the one under wordpress) is what tells Docker to surface the wp-content directory and the resulting WordPress directories in the local file system. You don’t have to change anything here, it’s a local path that is keyed off the directory the config.yml file is in. The wp-content directory along with the themes and plugins directories will be created automatically when we run the Docker command to install everything. So anything created by WordPress (e.g. adding a plugin through the admin panel) or you (uploading an image) will show up in these directories just like they would on a server.

The the second volumes parameter (db_data) persists the updates made by WordPress to the database.

Container upload limit

The default file upload limit for the WordPress container is 2 MB, which is not ideal for a local development environment. The solution is to increase the upload limit by specifying our own uploads.ini file:

file_uploads = On
memory_limit = 64M
upload_max_filesize = 64M
post_max_size = 64M
max_execution_time = 600

Build the project

The YAML file is ready to initialize the defined Docker container. Make sure you are running the command from the directory where your YAML file is located.

docker-compose up -d

This runs docker-compose up in detached mode, pulls the needed Docker images, and starts the WordPress and database containers.

Install WordPress

At this point, WordPress should be running on port 8000 (or if you changed the port number, on whatever port you changed it to) of your Docker Host, and you can complete the “famous five-minute installation” as a WordPress administrator.

Open http://localhost:8000/ in your browser and the standard WordPress installation screen should appear.

  • https://docs.docker.com/samples/wordpress/
  • https://upcloud.com/community/tutorials/wordpress-with-docker/
  • https://docs.docker.com/compose/reference/up/
